interactions:
Kayako - ticket id 60098171 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Ralph,

Thank you for your continued updates and for clarifying the persistent Failed (VSE) errors immediately after reinstalling GFI MailEssentials. I understand your frustration, especially since your configuration has not changed for years and you have already attempted both standard and non-clean reinstalls.

The Failed (VSE) error specifically indicates a malfunction in the Virus Scanning Engine (VSE) component of MailEssentials. This is a critical part of the email scanning process, and when it fails, all inbound emails are blocked from delivery. Based on your description and the troubleshooting already performed, here are the most targeted steps and considerations to address this:

1. Addressing the "Failed (VSE)" Error
The VSE error is most commonly caused by:

 	* Corrupted or outdated virus definition files
 	* Conflicts with other antivirus software on the server
 	* Insufficient permissions for the MailEssentials service account
 	* Residual files from previous installations causing conflicts

2. Clean Reinstallation Procedure (Preserving Configuration and Data)
To resolve persistent VSE errors, a clean reinstallation is recommended. This process removes all residual files that may be causing the issue, while allowing you to restore your configuration and historical data:

	* Backup Configuration and Data: 

 	* Backup the following folders (default paths shown, adjust if your installation uses custom paths):

 	* Configuration: C:\Program Files (x86)\GFI\MailEssentials\ (or C:\Program Files\GFI\MailEssentials\) – especially the Config, Antispam, Antivirus, and Quarantine subfolders.
 	* Data: C:\ProgramData\GFI\MailEssentials\ (or C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\GFI\MailEssentials\ on older systems).
 	* Custom Rules/Filters: Usually within the Config or Antispam subfolders.
 	* Quarantine and Historical Data: Backup the Quarantine folder and any related database files.

 	* If your version supports it, use the built-in export tool to save your configuration settings.

	* Uninstall MailEssentials: 

 	* Use the standard Windows uninstall process to remove MailEssentials.
 	* After uninstalling, manually delete any remaining MailEssentials folders from the installation and data directories to ensure no corrupted files remain.
 	* Reboot the server before proceeding.

	* Reinstall the Latest Version: 

 	* Download and install the latest version of GFI MailEssentials from the official site.

	* Restore Configuration and Data: 

 	* With MailEssentials services stopped, copy your backed-up configuration and data folders back to their original locations.
 	* Ensure the service account running MailEssentials has full permissions on all restored folders and files.
 	* Restart MailEssentials services and verify that the configuration and historical data are intact.

3. Additional Recommendations

 	* Ensure no other antivirus software is scanning MailEssentials directories or interfering with its processes. If present, configure exclusions for all MailEssentials folders.
 	* After reinstalling, check for updates to virus definitions and the scanning engine within MailEssentials.
 	* Monitor the logs for any recurring VSE errors or permission issues.

4. Reference Articles

 	* Emails Are Not Processing After Changing the Path of the Pickup or Replay Folders [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181259-Emails-Are-Not-Processing-After-Changing-the-Path-of-the-Pickup-or-Replay-Folders]
 	* Emails are not processed in the dashboard and a large number of temp files in the Windows Temp directory [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181219-Emails-are-not-processed-in-the-dashboard-and-a-large-number-of-temp-files-in-the-Windows-Temp-directory]
 	* MailEssentials is not processing emails and emails go to FailedMails folder [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181299-MailEssentials-is-not-processing-emails-and-emails-go-to-FailedMails-folder]
 	* A large number of emails are building up in the BadMail folder and queues [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/117334]

If you need clarification on any of the steps above or have questions about specific files or folders to back up and restore, please let me know and I will be happy to provide further guidance.

I understand your frustration and appreciate your patience as you work through this issue. If you have any specific error messages or log entries related to the VSE failures, sharing those details may help further isolate the root cause.

Sincerely,
Atlas
GFI - MailEssentials Support Team.

-------------------------

This response contains information generated with 3rd party components for which we disclaim all responsibility. For more details, you can check the terms and conditions at: chattbotterms.trilogy.com [https://chatbotterms.trilogy.com]

Kayako - ticket id 60098171 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Ralph,

Thank you for your continued updates and for clarifying the persistent Failed (VSE) errors immediately after reinstalling GFI MailEssentials, even when the installation is not a clean one. Based on your detailed troubleshooting and the fact that configuration has not changed for years, the consistent Failed (VSE) errors indicate a problem with the Virus Scanning Engine (VSE) component, which is preventing all inbound emails from being processed.

Here are comprehensive steps and recommendations to address the Failed (VSE) issue while preserving your configuration and historical data:

1. Understanding the "Failed (VSE)" Error
The "VSE" error typically points to a malfunction or corruption in the antivirus scanning engine within MailEssentials. Common causes include:

 	* Corrupted or outdated virus definition files
 	* Conflicts with other antivirus software on the server
 	* Insufficient permissions for the MailEssentials service account
 	* Residual files from previous installations causing conflicts

2. Steps for a Clean Reinstallation (Preserving Configuration and Data)

	* Backup Configuration and Data: 

 	* Backup the following folders (default paths shown, adjust if your installation uses custom paths):

 	* Configuration: C:\Program Files (x86)\GFI\MailEssentials\ (or C:\Program Files\GFI\MailEssentials\) – especially the Config, Antispam, Antivirus, and Quarantine subfolders.
 	* Data: C:\ProgramData\GFI\MailEssentials\ (or C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\GFI\MailEssentials\ on older systems).
 	* Custom Rules/Filters: Usually within the Config or Antispam subfolders.
 	* Quarantine and Historical Data: Backup the Quarantine folder and any related database files.

 	* If your version supports it, use the built-in export tool to save your configuration settings.

	* Uninstall MailEssentials: 

 	* Use the standard Windows uninstall process to remove MailEssentials.
 	* After uninstalling, manually delete any remaining MailEssentials folders from the installation and data directories to ensure no corrupted files remain.
 	* Reboot the server before proceeding.

	* Reinstall the Latest Version: 

 	* Download and install the latest version of GFI MailEssentials from the official site.

	* Restore Configuration and Data: 

 	* With MailEssentials services stopped, copy your backed-up configuration and data folders back to their original locations.
 	* Ensure the service account running MailEssentials has full permissions on all restored folders and files.
 	* Restart MailEssentials services and verify that the configuration and historical data are intact.

3. Additional Recommendations

 	* Ensure no other antivirus software is scanning MailEssentials directories or interfering with its processes. If present, configure exclusions for all MailEssentials folders.
 	* After reinstalling, check for updates to virus definitions and the scanning engine within MailEssentials.
 	* Monitor the logs for any recurring VSE errors or permission issues.

4. Reference Articles

 	* Emails Are Not Processing After Changing the Path of the Pickup or Replay Folders [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181259-Emails-Are-Not-Processing-After-Changing-the-Path-of-the-Pickup-or-Replay-Folders]
 	* Emails are not processed in the dashboard and a large number of temp files in the Windows Temp directory [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181219-Emails-are-not-processed-in-the-dashboard-and-a-large-number-of-temp-files-in-the-Windows-Temp-directory]

 	* A large number of emails are building up in the BadMail folder and queues [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/117334]

If you need clarification on any of the steps above or have questions about specific files or folders to back up and restore, please let me know and I will be happy to provide further guidance.

Sincerely,
Atlas

Kayako - ticket id 60098171 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Ralph,

Thank you for your follow-up and for clarifying your concern about preserving your configuration and historical data when considering a reinstallation of GFI MailEssentials. I understand the importance of not losing years of configuration and email history.

To retain your configuration and historical data, you will need to back up specific files and folders before uninstalling MailEssentials. Below are the key components you should preserve:

1. Configuration Files and Folders
MailEssentials stores its configuration in several locations, depending on your version and installation path. Typically, you should back up the following:

 	* MailEssentials Configuration Folder: By default, this is located at C:\Program Files (x86)\GFI\MailEssentials\ or C:\Program Files\GFI\MailEssentials\. Within this folder, pay special attention to subfolders such as Config, Antispam, Antivirus, and Quarantine.
 	* MailEssentials Data Folder: This may include logs, quarantine data, and other operational files. The default path is often C:\ProgramData\GFI\MailEssentials\ or C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\GFI\MailEssentials\ on older systems.
 	* Custom Rules and Filters: If you have created custom rules, filters, or whitelist/blacklist entries, ensure these files are included in your backup. They are usually found within the Config or Antispam subfolders.

2. Quarantine and Historical Data
If you wish to retain the quarantine and historical email data, back up the Quarantine folder and any related database files. These are typically found within the main MailEssentials installation directory or the data folder mentioned above.

3. Exporting Settings (Optional)
Some versions of MailEssentials provide a built-in export/import tool for configuration settings. If available, use this feature to create a backup of your settings before uninstalling. This can simplify the restoration process after reinstallation.

4. Restoring After Reinstallation
After performing a clean installation of MailEssentials, you can restore your configuration and data by copying the backed-up folders and files back to their original locations. Ensure that MailEssentials services are stopped before restoring files, and restart the services once restoration is complete.

Important Notes:

 	* Always ensure you have a full backup of your system and MailEssentials data before making any changes.
 	* If you are unsure about the exact file paths or need to confirm the location of specific configuration files, you can check the MailEssentials documentation or review the application settings for custom paths.
 	* After restoring, verify that permissions on the restored folders and files are correct, and that the MailEssentials service account has full access.

For further reference, you may find these articles helpful:

 	* Emails Are Not Processing After Changing the Path of the Pickup or Replay Folders [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181259-Emails-Are-Not-Processing-After-Changing-the-Path-of-the-Pickup-or-Replay-Folders]
 	* Emails are not processed in the dashboard and a large number of temp files in the Windows Temp directory [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181219-Emails-are-not-processed-in-the-dashboard-and-a-large-number-of-temp-files-in-the-Windows-Temp-directory]
 	* MailEssentials is not processing emails and emails go to FailedMails folder [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181299-MailEssentials-is-not-processing-emails-and-emails-go-to-FailedMails-folder]
 	* A large number of emails are building up in the BadMail folder and queues [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/117334]

If you need clarification on any of the steps above or have questions about specific files or folders, please let me know and I will be happy to provide further guidance.

Sincerely,
Atlas
GFI - MailEssentials Support Team.

-------------------------

Kayako - ticket id 60098171 // Ralph Venturino commented privately: What files are required for configuration. Not in a mood of redoing all from scratch and history data from the last X number of years.

Kayako - ticket id 60098171 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Ralph,

Thank you for your detailed updates and for clarifying that the configuration has remained unchanged for years, with the only recent observation being persistent Failed (VSE) errors for all scanned inbound emails, which in turn halted all email flow through GFI MailEssentials. I understand that uninstalling and reinstalling MailEssentials, as well as creating a new SMTP Virtual Server, did not resolve the issue, and that normal mail flow resumes only when MailEssentials is disabled.

Based on your description and the consistent Failed (VSE) errors, this points to a problem within the MailEssentials scanning engine or its integration with the SMTP service. Here are comprehensive steps and considerations to help you address this:

1. Investigate the "Failed (VSE)" Errors
The "VSE" typically refers to the Virus Scanning Engine. If all emails are failing at this stage, it may indicate a corruption or malfunction in the antivirus scanning component of MailEssentials. This can occur due to:

 	* Corrupted virus definition files or engine updates
 	* Conflicts with other antivirus software running on the server
 	* Insufficient permissions for the MailEssentials service account to access scanning components
 	* Outdated or incompatible MailEssentials installation with your current server environment

Recommended Actions:

 	* Clear Temporary and Definition Files: Stop the MailEssentials services and manually clear out the temporary files and virus definition folders. Upon restarting, MailEssentials will attempt to download fresh definitions.
 	* Check for Conflicting Antivirus Software: Ensure that no other antivirus software is scanning the same mail directories or interfering with MailEssentials processes. If present, configure exclusions for MailEssentials folders and processes.
 	* Update MailEssentials: Make sure you are running the latest version of MailEssentials, as updates often resolve compatibility and scanning engine issues.
 	* Review Permissions: Confirm that the service account running MailEssentials has full control over all related folders (Pickup, Replay, Queue, Temp, and definition folders).

For further reference, please review these relevant articles:

 	* Emails Are Not Processing After Changing the Path of the Pickup or Replay Folders [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181259-Emails-Are-Not-Processing-After-Changing-the-Path-of-the-Pickup-or-Replay-Folders]
 	* Emails are not processed in the dashboard and a large number of temp files in the Windows Temp directory [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181219-Emails-are-not-processed-in-the-dashboard-and-a-large-number-of-temp-files-in-the-Windows-Temp-directory]
 	* MailEssentials is not processing emails and emails go to FailedMails folder [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181299-MailEssentials-is-not-processing-emails-and-emails-go-to-FailedMails-folder]
 	* A large number of emails are building up in the BadMail folder and queues [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/117334]

2. Analyze Event and Application Logs
Since you have observed SMTP protocol and GFI sink errors, continue to review the Windows Event Viewer and MailEssentials logs for any specific error codes or messages related to the VSE failures. These logs can provide direct clues about the root cause, such as permission issues, file corruption, or engine initialization failures.

3. Consider a Clean Reinstallation
If the above steps do not resolve the issue, a clean reinstallation of MailEssentials may be necessary. This involves:

 	* Uninstalling MailEssentials
 	* Manually deleting any remaining MailEssentials folders (after backing up configuration if needed)
 	* Rebooting the server
 	* Reinstalling the latest version of MailEssentials

This process ensures that any corrupted files or settings are fully cleared before a fresh installation.

If you continue to experience Failed (VSE) errors after these steps, focus on the specific error messages in your logs, as they will be key to identifying the underlying cause. If you need clarification on any of the steps above or encounter specific error codes, please let us know the details so we can provide more targeted guidance.

Sincerely,
Atlas
GFI - MailEssentials Support Team.

-------------------------

Kayako - ticket id 60098171 // Ralph Venturino commented privately: As i stated, nothing changed on configuration. Has been the same for years. Only thing I noticed today was the Failed (VSE) errors for all scanned inbound emails, which in turn stopped all email flow going through GFI..

That's it...

Kayako - ticket id 60098171 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Ralph,

Thank you for your detailed updates and for sharing the troubleshooting steps you have already taken regarding the issue where emails are not delivered to user inboxes when GFI MailEssentials is enabled. I understand that you have attempted both uninstalling and reinstalling MailEssentials, as well as creating a new SMTP Virtual Server, but the problem persists with emails becoming stuck in the SMTP queue.

Based on your observations and the information available in our knowledge base, here are comprehensive steps and considerations to help address this persistent mail flow issue:

1. Review Pickup, Replay, and Queue Folder Configuration
MailEssentials relies on the correct configuration and accessibility of the Pickup, Replay, and SMTP queue folders to process and deliver emails. Please ensure that:

 	* The folder paths configured in MailEssentials exactly match those set in your Exchange or SMTP server.
 	* The folders are accessible and have not been moved, renamed, or had permissions changed.
 	* No antivirus or backup software is locking or interfering with these folders.

For more details, see: Emails Are Not Processing After Changing the Path of the Pickup or Replay Folders [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181259-Emails-Are-Not-Processing-After-Changing-the-Path-of-the-Pickup-or-Replay-Folders].

2. Inspect BadMail, FailedMails, and Temp Directories
A buildup of emails in the BadMail or FailedMails folders, or a large number of temporary files in the Windows Temp directory, can indicate a processing or delivery issue. Please check these locations for undelivered messages:

 	* MailEssentials is not processing emails and emails go to FailedMails folder [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181299-MailEssentials-is-not-processing-emails-and-emails-go-to-FailedMails-folder]
 	* Emails are not processed in the dashboard and a large number of temp files in the Windows Temp directory [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181219-Emails-are-not-processed-in-the-dashboard-and-a-large-number-of-temp-files-in-the-Windows-Temp-directory]
 	* A large number of emails are building up in the BadMail folder and queues [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/117334]

3. Confirm Service Account Permissions
The Windows account running the MailEssentials services must have full read/write permissions to the Pickup, Replay, SMTP queue, BadMail, and FailedMails folders. Insufficient permissions can prevent emails from being moved out of the queue and delivered to Exchange or the intended destination.

4. Analyze Event Logs and MailEssentials Logs
Since you have observed numerous SMTP protocol and GFI sink errors in the logs, it is important to:

 	* Review the specific error messages in the Windows Event Viewer and MailEssentials logs for clues about the underlying cause (e.g., protocol errors, access denied, file locking).
 	* Look for patterns or repeated error codes that may indicate a configuration or compatibility issue.

5. Check for Filtering or Quarantine Issues
If you are using filtering modules such as SpamRazer, ensure that legitimate emails are not being incorrectly blocked or quarantined. You can review and reprocess such emails as described in: MailEssentials is not processing emails and emails go to FailedMails folder [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181299-MailEssentials-is-not-processing-emails-and-emails-go-to-FailedMails-folder].

6. Consider SMTP Virtual Server Binding and Compatibility
When creating a new SMTP Virtual Server and binding GFI to it, ensure that:

 	* The new server is properly configured and recognized by both MailEssentials and Exchange.
 	* All necessary ports are open and not blocked by firewall or security software.
 	* There are no conflicts with other services or applications using the same SMTP resources.

If after reviewing these areas the issue persists, focus on the specific SMTP protocol and GFI sink errors in your logs, as these will provide the most direct clues to the root cause. Addressing any permission, configuration, or compatibility issues highlighted in the logs is key to restoring normal mail flow.

If you need further clarification on any of the steps above or encounter specific error messages that you would like to discuss, please let us know the details so we can provide more targeted guidance.

Sincerely,
Atlas
GFI - MailEssentials Support Team.

-------------------------

4. Analyze Event Logs and MailEssentials Logs
Since you have observed numerous SMTP protocol and GFI sink errors in the logs, it is important to:

 	* Review the specific error messages in the Windows Event Viewer and MailEssentials logs for clues about the underlying cause (e.g., protocol errors, access denied, file locking).
 	* Look for patterns or repeated error codes that may indicate a configuration or compatibility issue.

5. Check for Filtering or Quarantine Issues
If you are using filtering modules such as SpamRazer, ensure that legitimate emails are not being incorrectly blocked or quarantined. You can review and reprocess such emails as described in: MailEssentials is not processing emails and emails go to FailedMails folder [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181299-MailEssentials-is-not-processing-emails-and-emails-go-to-FailedMails-folder].

6. Consider SMTP Virtual Server Binding and Compatibility
When creating a new SMTP Virtual Server and binding GFI to it, ensure that:

 	* The new server is properly configured and recognized by both MailEssentials and Exchange.
 	* All necessary ports are open and not blocked by firewall or security software.
 	* There are no conflicts with other services or applications using the same SMTP resources.

7. Additional Reference
If you notice a large number of emails building up in the BadMail folder and queues, please refer to: A large number of emails are building up in the BadMail folder and queues [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/117334].

If after reviewing these areas the issue persists, focus on the specific SMTP protocol and GFI sink errors in your logs, as these will provide the most direct clues to the root cause. Addressing any permission, configuration, or compatibility issues highlighted in the logs is key to restoring normal mail flow.

If you need further clarification on any of the steps above or encounter specific error messages that you would like to discuss, please let us know the details so we can provide more targeted guidance.

Kayako - ticket id 60098171 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Ralph,

Thank you for your update. Based on your latest observation that emails appear to be stuck in the SMTP queue when GFI MailEssentials scanning is enabled, while disabling scanning allows immediate delivery, this strongly suggests an issue with the mail handoff process between MailEssentials and your Exchange server.

Here are targeted steps and references to help you resolve this scenario:

1. Review Pickup and Replay Folder Configuration
MailEssentials relies on the correct configuration of the Pickup and Replay folders to transfer processed emails to Exchange. If these paths are incorrect or inaccessible, emails may remain stuck in the SMTP queue. Please verify that the Pickup and Replay folder paths in MailEssentials exactly match those configured in Exchange. For detailed guidance, see: Emails Are Not Processing After Changing the Path of the Pickup or Replay Folders [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181259-Emails-Are-Not-Processing-After-Changing-the-Path-of-the-Pickup-or-Replay-Folders].

2. Inspect the BadMail and FailedMails Folders
If emails cannot be delivered, they may accumulate in the BadMail or FailedMails folders. Check these locations for undelivered messages. A large buildup here can indicate a persistent delivery issue. For more information, refer to: MailEssentials is not processing emails and emails go to FailedMails folder [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181299-MailEssentials-is-not-processing-emails-and-emails-go-to-FailedMails-folder] and Emails are not processed in the dashboard and a large number of temp files in the Windows Temp directory [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181219-Emails-are-not-processed-in-the-dashboard-and-a-large-number-of-temp-files-in-the-Windows-Temp-directory].

3. Confirm Service Account Permissions
Ensure that the Windows account running the MailEssentials services has full read/write permissions to the Pickup, Replay, and SMTP queue folders. Insufficient permissions can prevent emails from being moved out of the queue and delivered to Exchange.

4. Review Event Logs and MailEssentials Logs
Check the Windows Event Viewer and MailEssentials logs for any error messages or warnings related to mail transport, file access, or permissions. These logs can provide specific clues about why emails are not leaving the SMTP queue.

5. Inspect Filtering and Quarantine Settings
If you are using filtering modules such as SpamRazer, ensure that legitimate emails are not being incorrectly blocked or quarantined. You can review and reprocess such emails as described in: MailEssentials is not processing emails and emails go to FailedMails folder [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/hc/en-us/articles/360015181299-MailEssentials-is-not-processing-emails-and-emails-go-to-FailedMails-folder].

If after following these steps emails remain stuck in the SMTP queue, please review the logs for any specific error messages or patterns that could further isolate the cause. The articles above provide additional troubleshooting steps and examples for similar scenarios.

If you need clarification on any of the steps or encounter specific errors during your review, please let us know the details so we can provide more targeted guidance.
